Award.AwardTitle: 49erTeach: Building Capacity for Teachers of Chemistry and Physics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The University of North Carolina at Charlotte has established the UNC Charlotte 49er Teach Noyce Scholars Program to prepare 12 high-school chemistry and physics teachers with content expertise. Through a strong partnership among the Departments of Physics and Chemistry, the College of Education, and the Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools, this high-quality teacher preparation program uses the Learning Coach model to engage the best chemistry and physics students in peer instruction, supported by faculty mentors. Those selected to become Noyce Scholars enroll in pedagogy courses, attend seminars enriching their knowledge of both science and pedagogy, attend state and national meetings on science education, have summer internship opportunities, and are supported by a three-person team of mentors, one each from the science faculty, the education faculty, and a classroom teacher. Having completed the certification program, new teachers continue to be mentored and supported during their first three induction years. This project's success rests on its seamless collaborations among disparate disciplines, strong administrative support, and the well-developed Learning Coach model. It addresses a key need for well-trained high school chemistry and physics teachers, particularly in underserved areas such as rural North Carolina.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of North Carolina at Charlotte established the UNC Charlotte 49er Teach Noyce Scholars Program to prepare high-school chemistry and physics teachers with content and pedagogical expertise. This project was a partnership between the Center for STEM Education, the Departments of Chemistry and Physics, the College of Education, the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences, and the Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools.  This high-quality teacher preparation program used a Learning Coach model to engage the best chemistry and physics students in peer instruction, supported by faculty mentors. Those students selected to become Noyce Scholars enrolled in pedagogy courses, attended seminars enriching their knowledge of both science and pedagogy, attended state and national meetings on science education, and were supported by a three-person team of mentors, one each from the science faculty, the education faculty, and a classroom teacher. The program provided scholars with opportunities for professional development and participation in professional education groups such as National Science Teachers Association. This work addressed a key need for well-trained high school chemistry and physics teachers, particularly in urban areas as well as underserved areas in rural North Carolina. The program also served as a catalyst for promoting change in STEM education leading to collaboration that energized consideration for active learning models to improve undergraduate STEM teaching.
